ul.li: The United Ostomy Associations of America (UOAA) - offers support, advocacy, and educational information for those with an ostomy or continent diversion. Visit their site at https://www.ostomy.org/ for discussion boards, local support groups, and living tips.

he Colorectal Cancer Alliance - provides a list of ostomy support resources, including links to nurse societies and associations. Check it out at https://colorectalcancer.org/treatment/types-treatment/colostomy-and-ileostomy/ostomy-support-resources.

Convatec's me+ program - is a free support initiative with tools, advice, and personalized guidance for living confidently with an ostomy. Access it at https://www.convatec.com/ostomy-care/meplus-patient-support/.
stomy 101 features - information on colostomy, ileostomy, and urostomy, along with supplies, services, and support options. Their site is at https://www.ostomy101.com/.
Hollister - provides educational tools like videos, guides, and care tips for ostomy surgery and product use. Explore them at https://www.hollister.com/en/ostomycare/educationaltools.

The American Cancer Society - has a section on getting ostomy help, information, and support, including services for those without insurance. Find it at https://www.cancer.org/cancer/supportive-care/ostomies/getting-help-info-and-support.html.
Coloplast - offers advice, personalized support, and inspiration through their Care program for those with or preparing for an ostomy. Visit https://www.coloplast.us/ostomy/people-with-an-ostomy/.

Mayo Clinic - provides in-depth articles on adapting to life after colostomy, ileostomy, or urostomy to boost self-esteem and adjustment. Read more at https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/colon-cancer/in-depth/ostomy/art-20045825.
